title: Land, Labour and competition in early Greece
abstractText: A new approach to the history of the city-states of early Greece (750-450BC), which argues that one of the driving forces in their development was open-ended, status-driven competition for land and labour, often conducted by violent and other illegitimate means. The creation of new forms of exploitation in this period- including chattel slavery, debt-bondage and 'conquest serfdom' and attempts to resist such forms of exploitation did much to shape both the general patterns and the regional differences in the development of archaic Greek economy and society.
